title: 105_s626
content:
The Act titled "Stop Sweatshops Act of 1997" references the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. The Act includes findings related to its purpose. The Congress finds that the production of garments in violation of minimum labor standards hinders commerce and fair competition, especially in the domestic garment industry where working conditions are detrimental to workers' well-being. Most sweatshop employers fail to comply with recordkeeping requirements under the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. The amendment of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is necessary to hold manufacturers accountable for compliance with wage and hour laws in the garment industry, promoting fair competition and better working conditions for workers. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to establish legal responsibility for compliance with wage and hour provisions in the garment industry. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to hold manufacturers in the garment industry liable for violations committed by contractors in garment manufacturing operations. Manufacturers are subject to civil liability and penalties for violations of specific sections regulating industrial homework and other provisions. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to hold manufacturers in the garment industry liable for violations committed by contractors in garment manufacturing operations, including cutting, sewing, dyeing, washing, finishing, assembling, and pressing apparel for men, women, children, and infants. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to hold manufacturers in the garment industry liable for violations committed by contractors in garment manufacturing operations, including cutting, sewing, dyeing, washing, finishing, assembling, and pressing apparel for men, women, children, and infants. The term 'manufacturer' includes any person who contracts with a contractor to produce apparel items designed to be worn and sold. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to hold manufacturers in the garment industry liable for violations committed by contractors in garment manufacturing operations. This includes producing apparel items for men, women, children, and infants, such as clothing, hats, gloves, handbags, and hosiery. The term 'manufacturer' encompasses those responsible for the production of apparel items intended for sale to consumers. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to hold manufacturers in the garment industry jointly liable with contractors for violations in apparel production. This includes items like clothing, hats, gloves, handbags, and hosiery intended for sale to consumers. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to make manufacturers in the garment industry jointly liable with contractors for violations in apparel production, including clothing, hats, gloves, handbags, and hosiery intended for sale to consumers. The amendment includes changes to specify liability in the first or second sentence and allows for liability by a manufacturer in the garment industry. SEC. 4. RECORDKEEPING.

Amendment to Section 16(e) (29 U.S.C. 216(e)) imposes civil penalties for failure to maintain required payroll records and submission of fraudulent records. Penalties include up to $1,000 per employee for violations and $10,000 for each act of fraud, with higher penalties for repeat offenses.

SEC. 5. EFFECTIVE DATE. The amendments made by this Act will be effective 30 days after enactment.
